support_summary: ATXN3 regulates cytoskeleton function through its interaction with dynein, a motor protein essential for retrograde axonal transport and sorting of protein aggregates.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 acts as an adaptor protein that links polyubiquitinated substrates (misfolded protein aggregates) to the dynein motor protein complex. This facilitates the retrograde transport of these aggregates along microtubules towards the microtubule-organizing center (MTOC).
functions.effect_description: This interaction is crucial for the formation of aggresomes, which are perinuclear inclusion bodies where misfolded proteins are concentrated for degradation. Depletion of ATXN3 impairs this process.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 binds ubiquitinated cargo → ATXN3 links cargo to Dynein motor → Dynein transports cargo along microtubules → Aggresome formation at MTOC → Sequestration of toxic proteins
specific_effects: ATXN3 facilitates the retrograde transportation of substrates to the aggresomes.
Depletion of ATXN3 leads to decreased aggresome formation.
Dynein motors drive the retrograde transport of autophagosomes, which can contain protein aggregates, from distal axons to the soma.
